1 Intended Use
The mariPOC® test system is designed to be used for detection of pathogens from patients with acuteinfections.ThemariPOC®testsystemenablestheanalysisofdifferentpathogencombinations frompatientsamples(Figure1,Figure 2 andFigure3).Thecombinationisselectedaccordingtothe clinicalpicture,clinicalsymptoms,andtheageofthepatientifappropriate.Theproductisintended forinvitrodiagnosticprofessionaluse.TestsystemequippedwithmariPOC®+measuringprogramis intended primarily for laboratories. The manufacturer or manufacturer’s representative will familiarise the user organisation with the testsystem.
1.1 mariPOC® Respi+, Respi and Pharyn Tests
ThemultianalytemariPOC®Respi+,RespiandPharyntestsaredesignedtobeusedfordetectionof acute respiratory tract infection pathogens from nasopharyngeal or throat samples depending on the test (Figure 1). Sampling for the detection of viral pathogens should be done during viremia within 6 days from the onset of symptoms, preferably within 5 days. Viral loads decrease over time and virus antigens are not usually detectable after 6 to 7 days from the onset ofsymptoms.
The Pharyn test is intended to be used when there is clinical suspicion of pharyngitis. The group A streptococci method of the Pharyn test can be used for the detection of the pathogen in perianal streptococcal dermatitis. The Respi+ and Respi tests are intended to be used for other lower and upperrespiratorytractinfections.IntheRespi+andRespitests,theanalytestobetesteddependon the patient’s age. Pneumococcus is not measured in small children due to the high frequency of asymptomatic carriers (the Respi < 7 years old test). Test selection is patient-specific and is made with the measuringprogram.

Depending on the indication, the sample is collected either from the nasopharynx using a swab, aspirate or wash procedures, or from the pharynx or the perianal area using a swab procedure. Suitable flocked swabs are defined in Table 7.
Figure 1. Pathogens covered by the mariPOC® Respi+, Respi and Pharyn tests.
1.2 mariPOC® Quick Flu+, Quick Flu/RSV and Quick StrepA Tests
The mariPOC® Quick Flu+, Quick Flu/RSV and Quick StrepA (Figure 2) rapid tests are intended to be used for the detection of acute respiratory tract infection pathogens. The mariPOC® Quick Flu/RSV test detects influenza A and B viruses and respiratory syncytial virus and in addition to these the mariPOC® Quick Flu+ detects SARS coronavirus 2 from nasopharyngeal samples in 20 minutes.
ThemariPOC®QuickStrepAtestdetectsgroupAstreptococcifromthroatsamplein15minutes.The QuickStrepAtestmaybeusedforthedetectionofthepathogeninperianalstreptococcaldermatitis.
Sample collection is similar to Respi and Pharyn tests. The Quick tests can be selected from Combi+ and Combi tests plate (Table 4) only if the Quick feature is enabled in the measuring program.

1.3 mariPOC® SARS-CoV-2 Test
The mariPOC® SARS-CoV-2 test is intended to be used for the detection of the virus when there is a clinical suspicion of acute coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). The SARS-CoV-2 test detects SARS-CoV-1 and SARS-CoV-2. The sample collection is similar to Respitest.
1.4 mariPOC® Gastro and CDI Tests
The mariPOC® Gastro and CDI tests (Figure 3) are intended to be used for the detection of pathogens, causing gastroenteritis, from stool samples. The samples should be obtained from patients with symptoms of acute gastrointestinal infection, e.g. diarrhoea and/or vomiting.
Sampling for the detection of viral pathogens from a stool sample should be done within few days from the onset of symptoms. Viral loads decrease over time and virus antigens are not usually detectableafteraweek.Bacteriaaremoreprobablefindingsthanvirusesfromastoolsampleswhen the symptoms areprolonged.
The Gastro test enables the analysis of five different pathogens that cause similar symptoms at the onset of the gastrointestinal infection. The CDI test is intended to be used mainly when there is clinical suspicion of Clostridium difficile infection (CDI). The CDI test enables the analysis of CDI by detecting the presence of C. difficile GDH (C. difficile specific surface protein glutamate dehydrogenase) and C. difficile toxins A and B.
Figure 3. Pathogens and/or analytes covered by the mariPOC® Gastro and CDI tests.

3 Precautions and Safety Instructions
The mariPOC® test system is intended for in vitro diagnostic use by health care professionals. The users are advised to carefully read this User’s manual to be able to correctly use the mariPOC® test system.
The following cautions are used throughout this User’s manual:
-Safety! For safetyinstructions
-Note! For other important instructions for the correct use of thedevice
Handle all samples and waste materials as if they were capable of transmitting infectious agents. The detailed waste disposal instructions are described in chapter “8 Cleaning and Waste Disposal”.
Detailedsafetyinformationoftheproductsarefoundinseparate,productspecificsafetydatasheets (SDS).
The test system uses a strong laser light (Class 1 laser product EN 60825-1:2014, Third Edition; specificationsinTable 8)andmechanicalmovementforanalysingsamples.Forthisreasonnoforeign bodiesorbodypartsmaybeinsertedintotheanalyser.Theanalysercasing,otherthanthetestplate hatch and the plate carriage and the sample hatch, must not be opened. User exposure to laser radiation in normal use is negligible. Analyser does not have user serviceable partsinside.

4 Operating Conditions, Storage and Maintenance
The operating temperature range of the test system is +21±5°C. The expiration dates of the consumables are printed on the packages.
Theanalysermustbestoredonaflatplatformwiththesampleandtestplatehatchesclosed. The analyser must not be exposed to dust, high temperatures, strong vibrations, strong magneticfields,chemicalsorchemicalvapours.Theanalyserheatsinkmustnotbecovered. Thewastecontainerandthe Systemand Washsolutionbottlesmustbeplacedsothatthere isatleast1cmoffreespacearoundtheheatsink.Liquidsmustnotbesprayeddirectlyinside or on the analyser! See the analyser cleaning instructions in chapter 8. The preventative maintenance interval of the analyser is 6 months. Only a person authorized by the manufacturer may carry out installation, maintenance or moving of theanalyser.
The test plate, delivered in a foil bag, must be stored at +2 to +8°C. After the foil bag is opened,thetestplatemustimmediatelybeplacedinsidetheanalyser.Thetestplatemaybe handled only by grasping it on its outer edges, and it must not be placed on a dusty surface. Touching the base of the test plate is strictly prohibited (Figure 8)! The test plates used for sampleanalysisarefullytraceable(seechapter“7.3.6 Reading and Reporting of the Results”; “mariPOCresults”).Thetestplateisvalidfor30daysfromtheopeningofthefoilbagandits insertion into the analyser. The measuring program will report automatically if the test plate is out-of-date. If the test plate is not stored inside the analyser, it must be placed in a special storage rack (see chapter 7.5). The test plate storage rack must not be exposed to temperatures over60°C.

5 Test Principle
Performing mariPOC® tests consists of the following steps: sampling, entering the patient’s information into the user interface, sample pretreatment, inserting the sample into the analyser, andautomaticanalysisatoneortwotimepoints.PreliminaryresultsarereportedforRespi+,Respi, Gastro and CDI tests at 20 minutes and final results at 2 hours. Preliminary results are reported for SARS-CoV-2 test at 20 minutes and final results at 95 minutes. Preliminary results are reported for Pharyn test at 15 minutes and final results at 55 minutes. Preliminary results of Respi+, Respi and Pharyn tests can be omitted from the start-up settings by the manufacturer or field service. At the preliminary results, the test identifies and reports strong and moderately positive samples. At the finalresults,thetestidentifiesandreportslowpositivesamplesandnegativetestresults.Theresults are reported at one time point, including positive and negative results, for Quick StrepA test at 15 minutes and for Quick Flu+ and Quick Flu/RSV tests at 20minutes.
Analyte specific identification reactions are based on specific identification of viral or bacterial antigens with monoclonal or affinity purified polyclonal antibodies (immunometric detection). The fluorescence signal measured by the test system from an analyte specific reaction correlates positivelywiththeantigencontentofthesample.Thetestsystemcomparesthesignalreceivedfrom the test to the cut off values set by the manufacturer for positive test results. Based on this comparison,thesampleisreportedaspositive(+)ornegative(-).ForS.pneumoniaeapositiveresult is reported semi-quantitatively as + (very low), ++ (low), +++ (medium), or ++++ (high). For group A streptococci in the Pharyn test a positive result is reported semi-quantitatively as + (very low), ++ (low),or+++(high)at55minutetimepoint.At15minutetimepointonlyhighpositive(+++)results arereported.InQuickStrepAtestapositive(+)oranegative(-)resultisreportedat15minutetime point. For detailed guidance, see chapter “7.3.6 Reading and Reporting of the Results”.
The test system is equipped with an internal autoverification system, which estimates the technical quality and success of the analysis. If the criteria for a reliable test result are not met, the result is not reported (i.e., the analysis is failed). A failed measurement is indicated in red on the patient informationlist.Inthiscase,thesamplecanbereanalysedoranewpatientsamplecanbecollected. Internal test result verification of the measuring program utilizes predetermined parameters. This ensures the reliability of aresult.
6TestPerformance
In the mariPOC® test system, several pathogens are measured from one patient sample using separate immunochemical identification reactions. The imprecision of the assay signal (coefficient ofvariation)is5–10%forRespi+,Respi,SARS-CoV-2andPharyntestmethodsand3–22%forGastro and CDI test methods, according to the quantitative tests carried out by themanufacturer.

Symptoms of C. sordellii infection are pain, nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea. Cross- reaction with C. sordellii toxins is a known property of the mariPOC® toxin A/B test and some other commercially available C. difficile toxin tests. However, mariPOC® GDH test does not detect C. sordellii. Both the mariPOC® GDH and the Toxin A/B tests must be positive to confirm the positivity for CDI. 7.3 Performing the Test and Reading the Results
The clinical suspicion (indication) determines the sampling location, the selected test type, and the pretreatment of the sample. The test plate in use determines the target pathogen coverage of the test (see Table 4, Table 5 and Table 6).
7.3.1Sampling
For the Respi+, Respi, Respi < 7 years old, Quick Flu+, Quick Flu/RSV and SARS-CoV-2 tests, the sample is taken from the mucosa of the respiratory tract nasopharynx by rubbing with a swab or collectingastandardnasopharyngealaspirate.Theswabsamplingmustbedoneusingflockedswabs defined in the User’s manual (see Table 7). It is beneficial to use as large a swab as possible, considering patient size, because the sample volume directly affects test performance. Nasopharyngeal wash samples are not recommended because they are dilute. The manufacturer disclaims any responsibility if any other sample materials are used in the mariPOC® testsystem.
ForthePharynandQuickStrepAtests,thesampleistypicallytakenfromthethroatortheperianal area depending on the symptoms. The sampling must be done using flocked swabs defined in the User’smanual(seeTable 7).Arigidlargeswabisrecommendedtobeusedforsamplingbecausethe sampling volume has a direct effect on testperformance.
For the Gastro and CDI tests, the sample material is stool (faeces) from patients with symptoms of acute gastroenteritis. Stool sample should be collected to a clean container.
7.3.2Storage of Samples
Refrigerated storage of the samples for several days, or freeze-thaw cycles, are known to have a deleteriouseffectonthesensitivityofallantigendetectiontests.Itisrecommended,therefore,that the sample is analysed as soon as possible following sampling. See Table 19for manufacturer’s recommendations for storage temperatures and times. Before analysis, nasopharyngeal and throat swabsamplescanbestoredinRTIsamplebuffer.However,swabsamplesarepreferredtobestored without the sample buffer. The mariPOC® Sample tube must be frozen in upright position with parafilmsealingthecaptopreventanyleakage.Thawthefrozensampletotallybeforepretreatment.

7.3.3 Respi+, Respi, Respi < 7 Years Old, Quick Flu+, Quick Flu/RSV and SARS-CoV-2 Tests
The pretreatment of the swab, aspirate and wash samples differs and in this manual they are referred to as A (swab), B (aspirate), C (wash, concentration protocol) and D (wash). Each sample type’s pretreatment procedures are described separately in this chapter in between printing the sample bar code and inserting the pretreated sample into the analyser.
Printing Bar Code
Click the new sample button in the top left corner of the mariPOC® Software. The “Patient information” pop-up window (Figure 12) opens. Enter patient information into at least one of the following fields: First name, Last name, and ID code (identifier). Depending on the test plate in use, selectthetesttypeRespi+,Respi,Respi<7yearsold,QuickFlu+,QuickFlu/RSVorSARS-CoV-2from the“Testtype”drop-downmenu.Thepathogensdetectedwiththeselectedtesttypearevisualised totherightside(thereportsection)ofthemariPOC®Softwareuntiltheresultsarereported(Figure11).
Respi+ and Respi tests detect 11 pathogens and reports the preliminary results in 20 minutes and final results in 2 hours. Respi+ test includes a test method for SARS-CoV-2. 7.3.6Reading and Reporting of theResults
The test reactions are automatically measured at one or two time points (Table 20) unless the preliminary time point has been omitted. At the preliminary results, the test identifies and reports strong and moderately positive samples. At the final results, the test identifies and reports low positive samples and negative test results. The result is reported with a positive (+) or negative (-) symbol.
For S. pneumoniae a positive result is reported semi-quantitatively as + (very low), ++ (low), +++ (medium), or ++++ (high). In the Pharyn test, group A streptococci positive result is reported semi- quantitatively as + (very low), ++ (low), or +++ (high) (see chapter “6 Test Performance”; Table 12). Optionally, reporting of + (very low) can be selected out when the test system is installed. The sensitivity of the Quick StrepA test and the preliminary result phase of group A streptococci test in the Pharyn test correspond approximately standard culture.
A red exclamation mark (!) next to the negative result in the column is indicating that a positive preliminary result has changed into a negative final result. A sound signal is played from the computerwhenpreliminaryresultsorQuicktestresultsbecomeavailable.Thesoundcanbemuted from computer soundsettings.
Additional quantitative information (see instructions from Table 22) about the pathogen levels in thesamplecanbeprovidednexttothequalitativeresultincolumnΨ,psiinthemeasuringprogram. Ψfeatureisoptional.Samplesobtainedfrommucosaarebytheirnaturesemi-quantitativeandare subjecttovariabilityinsampling.However,insomecasestheresultquantificationmaystillbeuseful in clinical practice. If reporting of Ψ values is in use, the preliminary phase identifies strong and moderately positive samples and reports them with a positive (+) symbol or with a borderline (+/-) symbolincasetheassaysignalisslightlybelowthecutoff.Thefinalresultisreportedwithapositive (+), borderline (+/-) or negative (-) symbol. Borderline result (+/-) should always be considered by default as negative unless result interpretation is used (see Table 22). For S. pneumoniae the borderline (+/-) result is reported only with the preliminary result. For group A streptococci, Gastro and CDI tests borderline (+/-) results are not reported. Qualitative reporting of the results is summarized in Table20.

1 GDH test Toxin A/B test Interpretation of the results
2 - - C. difficile or its toxins A and/or B are not present in the sample. The disease is very unlikely caused by C. difficile.

5 - + Invalid result. The sample should be reanalysed from the naïve stool sample. If the results persist after retesting, consider using other methods to confirm the results. In rare cases, the infection may be caused by highly pathogenic C. sordellii (see chapters 6.2 and 10.3).

7.8 Switching the Analyser Off and On
Both the analyser and the measuring program must be kept switched on because of the automatic rinsing of the test system. If the test system will not be used for long period of time (i.e., more than one week), it can be shut down in a controlled manner. This is done by selecting “Shutdown analyser”fromthe“Maintenancewizard”,whichisaccessedthroughthe“Moreoptions”drop-down menu of the mariPOC® Software. Follow the instructions. Remember to empty the waste container and change both the Wash and the System solution bottles with caps (and tubes) into water bottles pre-filled with deionized or distilled water. Finally, the program instructs the analyser to switch off viathepowerswitchonitsbackpanel(topleftcorner).Afterthat,themeasuringprogramprompts the user to click the “Finish” button. The measuring program will then close automatically. The test plate can then be changed or removed from the analyser. Next, the label printer, the computer and the analyser should also be switched off. When the test system is used again first switch on the analyser and then the computer and label printer. Open the measuring program from the short-cut icon on the desktop (Figure 43) and follow the on-screen instructions. Note that the water bottles must to be replaced with new Wash and System solution bottles. Empty and store the used water bottles until their nextuse.

8Cleaning and WasteDisposal
Cleaning
If surfaces get contaminated with respiratory sample or test System solutions, the cover of the analyser and other surfaces can be wiped with a cloth moistened with water or a mild cleaning solution. The cover and other surfaces can be disinfected with a disposable cloth moistened with 70% ethanol or similar when needed.
If surfaces get contaminated with stool sample, wipe the visible stain with disposable paper and clean the area first with a disposable paper moistened with detergent. Then clean the area with chlorinesolution(preferably1000ppm)becauseseveralfaecalpathogens(e.g.norovirus,C.difficile spores) tolerate cleaning with ethanol. For the final cleaning use water or/and 70% ethanol (or similar) to remove chlorine residues. Additionally Ultraviolet C (UV-C) light can beused.
If solution from e.g. sample tube or wash station has leaked inside the analyser, please contact the customer support. Visible stains in the analyser inside or cover can be cleaned as instructed above. This cleaning recommendation applies also to the other electric devices (e.g. vortex) unless otherwise stated in their User’s manual. Liquids must not be sprayed directly inside or on the analyser or other electric devices.
Filtration unit rack, required when handling a stool sample, and test plate storage rack can be cleaned mechanically by brushing with a detergent solution. The rack can be disinfected with chlorine solution (e.g. 1000 ppm) and/or Ultraviolet C (UV-C) light. Remember to properly rinse the rackaftercleaningwithwateror/and70%ethanol(orsimilar).Pleasenote,thatbothrack’smaterial does not tolerate temperatures over 60°C such as in dishwasher orautoclave.
Waste Disposal
The plastic consumables used to carry out tests, such as used test plates, sampling swabs, swabs in transport tube, syringe, filter, Pasteur pipette, sample tubes and caps may contain infectious materials.Theymustbedisposedofappropriately.Anunusedtestplatecanbedisposedwithnormal waste. The foil bag is suitable for metal recycling. The used or expired RTI or Gastro sample buffer, SystemandWashsolutions,ExtractionsolutionBandthecontentsofthewastecontainerandwater bottles can be poured into the drain taking into account the local legislation and the precautions mentionedintheUser’smanualandsafetydatasheets.TheWashsolutionisdesignedtoinactivate microbes. However, the waste should be considered potentially infectious and safety precautions should be followed when disposing thewaste.
When disposing the used or expired Extraction solution A, take into account local legislation and the precautions for the disposal of sodium nitrite. Empty storage containers (except the waterbottles), unused plastic components, silica gel bags, and protective wraps can be disposed with normal waste or recycled according to their material. The manufacturer is responsible for the appropriate disposal of the analyser components.
9Remarks
The patient’s clinical information must be taken into account when interpreting the results. The diagnosisofthepatient’sdiseasemustalwaysbedonebyahealthcareprofessionalwithasufficient level of education. The function of the test is to assist the professional making the diagnosis by providing limited information on the microbiological content of thesample.
Those samples that give a negative result may be verified using gene amplification tests (e.g., PCR). This is recommended especially for critically ill patients, and it is advised that also positive results from such are verified using an independent method. Those samples that give positive test results can be further typed using, for example, gene amplification tests or immunodiagnostic tests. The methodologicalsuitabilityofusingaleftoversamplefromthemariPOC®testsysteminanothertest, and the stability of the sample, must be validated appropriately. For swab sampling, only the swabs defined in the Table 7must be used. The nasopharyngeal aspirate and stool sample must be untreated(i.e.,nativeornaïve).Nasopharyngealwashsampleisnotapreferredsamplematerial.
Theresultsarereliableonlyifthesamplingandpretreatmenthavebeenappropriateandthetestis usedinaccordancewiththeinstructionsgiveninthisUser’smanual.Correctandcarefulsamplingis of utmost importance for test success. Swab and aspirate sampling for the detection of viral pathogens should be done during viremia within 6 days from the onset of symptoms, preferably within5days.Nasopharyngealwashsamplingshouldbedoneduringviremiawithin5daysfromthe onset of symptoms. Viral loads decrease over time and virus antigens are not usually detectable after 6 to 7 days from the onset of symptoms.
Samples should not be stored in any kind of transport or storage media or buffers. The preferred wayofstoringthesamplesisintheirnaïveform.Transportandstoragemediaandbufferscanaffect adversely to the stability of the sample and the performance of thetest.
The performance specifications stated by the manufacturer in terms of analytical and clinical sensitivity are valid for samples obtained using flocked swabs or by aspiration without saline. If the observed performance with nasopharyngeal wash samples does not match with the specifications of the manufacturer or the results reported in the literature, please use nasopharyngeal swabs and/or aspirates (no saline addition), which are primarily recommended by the manufacturer.
Recently administered oral rotavirus vaccine may give a positive result in the rotavirus test.
mariPOC® toxin A/B method of the CDI test cross-reacts with toxins produced by C. sordellii. Cross- reaction with C. sordellii toxins is a known property of the mariPOC® toxin A/B test and some other commerciallyavailableC.difficiletoxinA/Btests.However,mariPOC®GDHtestdoesnotcross-react with C. sordellii. See chapters 6.2 and 10.3 for moreinformation.
mariPOC®+measuringprogramisprimarilyintendedforlaboratories.Alongwithqualitativeresults, it provides quantitative information about the microbe levels in the sample (indicated in the measuringprogram’sresultscolumnΨ,psi).Mucosalsamplesarebytheirnaturesemi-quantitative atbestwithrespecttomicrobialloadinthetissue.Therefore,theresultsaresubjecttovariabilityin sampling. Optionally, reporting of Ψ values can be selected out when the test system isinstalled.
The sensitivity and specificity stated by the manufacturer are derived from the default positive and negativeresults,whicharebasedonthepresetcutoffs.Thedefaultresultsshouldonlybechanged upon joint decision of the laboratory and medical doctor responsible of the patient. Such decision shall be based on other significant evidence, such as other laboratory, epidemiological, and/or clinical information to increase the accuracy of the test result. Otherwise accuracy willsuffer.
Analyser is basic electromagnetic equipment (class A; CISPR 11:2009, 5:3). The system is intended to be used in light-industrial locations such as laboratories.
The computer used with the mariPOC® test system should not be connected to an information network without manufacturer’s authorization. The computer can be connected to a mobile network temporarily if instructed by the manufacturer or manufacturer’s representative e.g. when problem situations are solved via remote access.
If more than one test system is being used in the same department, care must be taken not to mix the test plates and the sample tubes between the test systems. The analyser identifies the sample tube by its bar code label and does not allow it to be reused: i.e., the used bar codes are both analyser and measuring program-specific. A sample tube bar code created by another test system will not be recognized and thus the sample will not be analysed. Additionally, one analyser will not identify test plates partially or completely used by another analyser, so that inserting the used test plate in another analyser will with high probability give wrong results.
Themanufacturerhasdesignedthetestsystemsothatcross-contaminationfromonesampleortest to another is rare. Carelessness in sample pretreatment can, however, lead to cross-contamination and therefore the interpretation of results must be carefully reviewed in relation to the patient information.
Each test marked as RUO is intended for research use only. Results from such tests with RUO status should not be used for clinical diagnostics. The manufacturer or its representative provides separately more information about RUO tests.
10Possible Problem Situations and PotentialSolutions
10.1 When to Contact Customer Support
The test system malfunction is typically indicated with an error notification in the dialogue window. Contactcustomersupportimmediatelyifthefaultdiagnosisandrepairinstructionspresentedinthe chapters below do not result in a functioning test system. Examples of issues requiring immediate customer supportare:
The analyser, or the measuring program, isunresponsive.
Recurrent failedresults.
Unexpected results for the controlsamples.
A flooded washing station caused, for example by a flooding waste container or a blockage in the washing station or itstube.
A bent or detached dispensingneedle.
Faulty operation of the sample tube rack, the sample hatch, the plate carriage or the test plate hatch.
Abnormal sounds.
Foreign bodies inside theanalyser.
10.2 Problems when Using the Test System
Problem: The analyser does not respond to the commands given in the measuring program. The results are not completed.
AB
1 Reason for the problem Solution / Action
2 The connection between the computer and the analyser is disturbed or has disconnected. Check that the analyser power is switched on and that the Ethernet cables between the analyser and the computer are connected. Make sure the Ethernet switch is turned on. Try to close the measuring program by clicking on the cross in the top right corner of the main window. If the measuring program closes, start it again from the short-cut icon on the desktop. If the problem persists, contact customer support.
Problem: The bar code reader does not recognize a sample tube.
AB
1 Reason for the problem Solution / Action
2 The sample tube bar code is the wrong way round or is at the wrong height, or the bar code label has been attached diagonally or crosswise, or is wrinkled. Rotate the sample tube so that the patient’s name is visible through the gap in the sample tube rack and then close the sample hatch. If this does not help, double-click the patient information line to open the “Patient information” window and print a new bar code label. Insert the sample tube into the sample tube rack gently to prevent it from getting stuck.
3 Please note message: “Too old sample tube at pos.” (i.e., bar code has been printed over 24 hours ago), or Warning messages: “Already dispensed sample tube at pos.” (i.e. the sample has already been dispensed) or “Unknown sample tube at pos.” (i.e., the bar code label is not recognized. Re-enter the patient information and print a new bar code label. The old bar code label may need to be detached. Make sure that the sample solution has not expired (storage instructions are found in chapter 7.3.2). If the sample has expired, a new sample should be taken from the patient. Insert the sample tube gently into the sample tube rack to prevent it from getting stuck.
4 The operation of the bar code reader or measuring program has slowed down or ended. The bar code reader is broken. Contact customer support.
Problem: The analyser does not accept the control samples.
AB
1 Reason for the problem Solution / Action
2 The control sample has expired or its processing in the analyser has not begun within two (2) hours of reading the bar code. Make sure that the control sample expiry has not passed. In the case that the control sample has been pending for more than two (2) hours, for example due to a test plate change, the measuring program will automatically reject it. Repeat the test using new control samples.
Problem: Analyser does not accept the positive control.
AB
1 Reason for the problem Solution / Action
2 Control samples were inserted into the analyser but the positive control was rejected (notification prompted). Negative control was analysed. Analyse new control samples and make sure the package is for correct test plate: REF 1104MC for mariPOC® Respi+, mariPOC® Respi, mariPOC® RTI combi+, mariPOC® RTI combi, mariPOC® Quick combi+ and mariPOC® Quick combi test plates, REF 1204SC for mariPOC® SARS-CoV-2 test plate, REF 1104MC or 1124MC for mariPOC® Pharyn test plate and REF 2017MC for mariPOC® Gastro, CDI and Gastro CDI combi test plates. Contact customer support if the problem continues.
3 Control samples were inserted into the analyser but the positive control was rejected without a notification. Negative control was analysed. Rotate the positive control tube so that the text is visible through the gap in the sample tube rack and then close the sample hatch. Contact customer support if the problem continues.
Problem: The sample hatch will not lock.
AB
1 Reason for the problem Solution / Action
2 A measurement is in progress. Wait 30 seconds. The sample hatch should lock after the measurement is finished.
3 The sample hatch has not been closed properly. Open the sample hatch slightly and close it again. Make sure that the sample hatch is fully closed. Contact customer support if the problem persists.
Problem: The System solution has run out.
AB
1 Reason for the problem Solution / Measure Solution / Action
2 The notification to change System solution bottle has been ignored. The test performance may have impeded by Wash solution residues. Change the System solution bottle in accordance with the “Change system solution container” instruction found on the “Maintenance wizard”, which can be opened from the drop-down menu “More options”.
Problem: The Wash solution has run out.
AB
1 Reason for the problem Solution / Measure Solution / Action
2 The notification to change Wash solution bottle has been ignored. Possible cross-contamination between samples. Change the Wash solution bottle in accordance with the “Change wash solution container” instruction found on the “Maintenance wizard”, which can be opened from the drop-down menu “More options”. Interpret the results with caution.
Problem: The use of Extraction solutions in the Pharyn or Quick StrepA test has been forgotten.
AB
1 Reason for the problem Solution / Action
2 Sample processing contrary to the instructions. If the Streptococcus group A analysis gives a negative result, this should be reported with caution. If necessary, take a new patient sample and process it in accordance with the instructions. The Extraction solutions significantly enhance the analytic sensitivity of the group A streptococci analysis.
Problem: There is white powder or dirt on the dispensing needle or the top surface of the washing station.
AB
1 Reason for the problem Solution / Action
2 Some solution components, such as salt or washing agent, have dried. Carefully rub the material with a swab moistened with purified water. Avoid bending the dispensing needle. If this does not help, contact customer support.
Problem: The bar code label does not get printed.
AB
1 Reason for the problem Solution / Action
2 The label tape has run out. Change to a new label tape cartridge. If the bar code label does not print automatically after the repair measures, double-click the patient information line to reopen the “Patient information” window. The bar code label can be printed again, but the information entered cannot be changed.
3 The computer is not communicating with the label printer. Check whether the label printer power is on (indicated by a green light is on the front) and that it is connected to the computer with a cable. Turn the label printer back on again. If the bar code label does not print automatically after the repair measures, double-click the patient information line to reopen the “Patient information” window. The bar code label can be printed again, but the information entered cannot be changed.
4 Error notification: “Label printer does not recognize the label tape”. Switch the label printer off and turn it back on again. If this does not help, try to put the label tape cartridge back in the printer. The bar code label can be printed again by double-clicking the patient information line to open the "Patient information” window.
10.3Problems with Results
Problem: The status of the analysis (Test status) is indicated in red text. One or more analysis has failed (i.e. no result is obtained and the text “Failed” appears after the analyte in the results).
AB
1 Reason for the problem Solution / Action
2 The total sample volume is too small (pretreatment has failed); the analyser cannot aspirate enough of the sample in the dispensing system. The solution level should be about halfway of the sample tube height. Reanalyse the sample. Re-enter the patient information and print a new bar code label. Remove the old bar code before attaching the new one. Check that the adjusted volume in the bottletop dispenser is 1.3 ml. Make sure that the bottletop dispenser piston is lifted to the top position. Throat swab sample: Make sure that RTI sample buffer, in addition to Extraction solutions A and B, has been added to the sample. If RTI sample buffer has been forgotten, add 1.3 ml of RTI sample buffer with the bottletop dispenser. If there is RTI sample buffer in the sample tube, add approximately 0.5 ml of the RTI sample buffer to the sample tube, and vortex for 10–15 seconds. Nasopharyngeal swab sample: Make sure that RTI sample buffer has been added to the sample. If RTI sample buffer has been forgotten, add 1.3 ml of RTI sample buffer with the bottletop dispenser. If there is RTI sample buffer in the sample tube, add approximately 0.5 ml of the RTI sample buffer to the sample tube, and vortex for 10–15 seconds. Aspirate sample: Sample to be reanalysed after addition of RTI sample buffer must be vortexed for 10–15 seconds and centrifuged before inserting it into the analyser. Stool sample: For a failed stool sample repeat the sample pretreatment. Check that the stool sample (flocked swab) was diluted into two volumes of the Gastro sample buffer (2x 1.3 ml) and that the pretreated sample solution volume in the Gastro sample tube is at or above the volume mark pointed in the filtration unit rack. If there is no naïve sample left, re- filter the pretreated sample. Before re-filtering, add Gastro sample buffer (if needed) until the total sample volume is approximately 2.3 ml to ensure enough (1.3 ml) flow-through after the second filtration. However, please note that dilution may have a negative effect on the test sensitivity.
AB
1 Reason for the problem Solution / Action
2 Dispensing has failed. Difficult sample material or the filter in stool sample pretreatment was faulty. The sample solution may be too viscous (mucous) or contain particular material. Reanalyse the sample. Re-enter the patient information and print a new bar code label. Remove the old bar code before attaching the new one. Throat/nasopharyngeal swab sample: Add approximately 1 ml of the RTI sample buffer to the failed sample, and vortex for 10–15 seconds. The solution level should be over 2/3 of the sample tube height. Aspirate sample: Sample to be reanalysed after addition of RTI sample buffer must be vortexed for 10–15 sec and centrifuged before inserting it into the analyser. Stool Sample: Check that the stool sample was pretreated (filtered) as instructed. Make the pretreatment again from the naïve stool sample if there is sample left. If there is no naïve sample left, re-filter the pretreated sample. Before re-filtering, add Gastro sample buffer (if needed) until the total sample volume is approximately 2.3 ml to ensure enough (1.3 ml) flow-through after the second filtration. However, please note that dilution may have a negative effect on the test sensitivity.
3 The dilution of the Pharyn or Quick StrepA test (done automatically on the test plate) has failed because the System solution has run out. Change to a new System solution bottle immediately using the Maintenance wizard. The sample must be reanalysed. Re-enter the patient information and print a new bar code label. Remove the old bar code before attaching the new one. Addition of RTI sample buffer to sample tube is not needed. Insert the sample tube into the sample tube rack gently to prevent it from getting stuck. Vortex the sample tube for 10–15 seconds. The measuring program calculates consumption of System solution and will not work correctly if a user changes the bottle before a notification is given by the measuring program or if a notification is ignored.
4 Control samples were inserted to the analyser without addition of test specific sample buffer and vortexing. Analyse a new set of control samples and make the pretreatment as instructed in chapter 7.4.
Problem:Theresultsgiveareasontosuspectthatthesamplesarecross-contaminated.Forexample, a negative control sample gives a positive result or a borderline result (+/-) in two or more consecutive controlruns.
AB
1 Reason for the problem Solution / Action
2 The RTI sample buffer or the dispensing head of the bottletop dispenser is contaminated (cross- contamination). Clean the outside of the bottletop dispenser by wiping with 70% ethanol or similar. Dispense 10 times into the drain to rinse the dispensing head. Change to a new RTI sample buffer bottle and dispense 10 times into the drain again. If required, the bottletop dispenser can be autoclaved by following the manufacturer’s instructions. Remember to recalibrate the dispenser after autoclaving.
3 The Gastro sample buffer or the dispensing head of the bottletop dispenser is contaminated (cross- contamination suspicion). Clean the outside of the bottletop dispenser by wiping the visible stain with disposable paper and then with disposable paper moistened with detergent. Then clean the outside with chlorine solution (preferably 1000 ppm) because several faecal pathogens (e.g. norovirus, C. difficile spores) tolerate cleaning with ethanol. For the final cleaning use water or/and 70% ethanol (or similar) to remove chlorine residues from the dispensing head. Dispense 10 times into the drain to rinse the dispensing head. Additionally, Ultraviolet C (UV-C) light or autoclave can be used. Remember to follow the manufacturer’s instructions and recalibrate the dispenser after autoclaving. Change to a new Gastro sample buffer bottle and dispense 10 times into the drain.
4 Between samples, the scissors have not been adequately cleaned. Check the procedure for cleaning the scissors. Clean the scissors carefully between samples using 70% ethanol or similar and then wiping them with disposable paper.
5 The Wash solution has run out. Change a new Wash solution bottle immediately. Select “Change wash solution container” from the “Maintenance wizard” that can be opened from the drop-down menu “More options”. Interpret the results with caution. The measuring program calculates consumption of Wash solution and will not work correctly if a user changes the bottle before a notification is given by the measuring program or if a notification is ignored.
Problem: The result for a negative control sample is reported with a borderline symbol +/-.
AB
1 Reason for the problem Solution / Action
2 The analysis signal of negative samples or negative controls can occasionally be close to the cut off due to statistical reasons. Nevertheless, borderline result is lower than the clinical cut off set by the manufacturer for reporting of positive findings. Result for a negative control with a borderline symbol (+/-) should be considered by default as negative.
Problem: The result for a positive control sample is negative.
AB
1 Reason for the problem Solution / Action
2 The test reagents or the control sample have been spoiled or the control sample treatment instructions, for example mixing and/or settling, have not been followed. Make sure that the test plate or the control sample have not been stored contrary to the instructions and that the control sample pretreatment length has been in accordance with the instructions. The control sample must not be treated with the Extraction solutions intended for the Pharyn and Quick StrepA test methods. Repeat the test using a new control sample. If the negative result recurs, contact customer support.
Problem: 3 or more positive virus results from a single patient sample.
AB
1 Reason for the problem Solution / Action
2 HAMA (human anti-mouse antibody) response or other interfering agent causes unspecific binding in the antigen detection reaction. There are multiple pathogens (e.g. sewer water based illness). Consider the results with caution and compare the results to existing clinical and epidemiological data. Throat/nasopharyngeal swab sample: If possible, resample the patient. Reanalysing the respiratory sample can reduce the amount of interference and increase the reliability of analysis. However, there is a risk that some false positives still remain and this complicates the use of the result in clinical decision-making. If you decide to reanalyse the sample, add approximately 1 ml of the RTI sample buffer to the failed sample, and vortex for 10–15 seconds. The solution level should be about 2/3 of the sample tube height. Re-enter the patient information and print a new bar code label. Remove the old bar code before attaching the new one. Aspirate sample: Sample to be reanalysed after addition of RTI sample buffer must be vortexed for 10–15 sec and centrifuged before inserting it into the analyser. Stool sample: Repeat the sample pretreatment or resample the patient if possible. Reanalysing the stool sample after freeze-thaw treatment may reduce the amount of interference and increase the reliability of analysis. However, there is a possibility that some false positives still remain and this complicates the use of the result in clinical decision-making. Consider using other methods to confirm the results. Note, however, that the interfering agent may also affect the reliability of other methods.
Problem: C. difficile GDH test gives a negative while Toxin A/B test gives a positive result.
AB
1 Reason for the problem Solution / Action
2 C. difficile GDH negative but Toxin A/B positive result might have been caused by cross-reaction with C. sordellii toxins. Negative GDH but positive toxin A/B result should be considered invalid by default. Make the pretreatment again from the naïve stool sample if there is sample left. If there is no naïve sample left, re-filter the pretreated sample. Before re-filtering, add Gastro sample buffer (if needed) until the total sample volume is approximately 2.3 ml to ensure enough (1.3 ml) flow-through after the second filtration. However, please note that dilution may have a significant effect on the test sensitivity. Cross-reaction with C. sordellii toxins is a known property of the mariPOC® Toxin A/B test and some other commercially available C. difficile toxin tests. C. sordellii toxins are homologous to toxins produced by C. difficile. C. sordellii is a pathogen with clinical relevance. Therefore, if the results persist after re-analysis, C. sordellii should be suspected and further tested with other methods.
Problem: Not enough sample solution in the Gastro/CDI sample tube after filtration.
AB
1 Reason for the problem Solution / Action
2 Too little Gastro sample buffer was used to suspend the sample, filter was blocked, there was too much of stool in the swab or the stool was too firm. Make the pretreatment again from the naïve stool sample if there is sample left. Pay attention to the Gastro sample buffer amount. If the sample volume is still not sufficient (≥1.3 ml) after filtration, combine the two pretreated samples. If there is no naïve sample left, re-filter the pretreated sample. Add Gastro sample buffer until the total sample volume is approximately 2.3 ml to ensure enough (1.3 ml) flow-through after the second filtration. However, please note that dilution may have a significant effect on the test sensitivity.
Problem: There is a red exclamation mark (!) next to the negative result.
AB
1 Reason for the problem Solution / Action
2 A positive preliminary result was changed into a negative result in the final analysis. Incorrect positive preliminary result may be due to an interfering substance present in the sample. The substance is most often inactivated during the incubation. Report the result as a negative finding. The final result is more specific than the rapid preliminary result.
